
# USH II Units 1 & 2 Assessment

## ESSENTIAL QUESTIONS

- To what extent was industrialization a benefit or a detriment to America in terms of politics, economics, society and culture?
    
- To what extent did industrialization, Populism, and Progressivism change what was perceived as the ‚ÄúAmerican Dream‚Äù?
    
- How can Populism and Progressivism be interpreted as radical or conservative movements and how have they impacted American life over the last century?
    

## Unit 1: The American Land¬†

### Chapter 22: The Ordeal of Reconstruction

The Heritage of Reconstruction

- How did most white Southerners regard the condition of Reconstruction? Why?
    
- What does Kennedy (the author) claim about the leaders of the US during Reconstruction with respect to their ‚Äúvision‚Äù of it?
    
- How did the Republicans act with respect to Reconstruction?
    
- Kennedy maintains that the South wasn‚Äôt reconstructed, but was resurrected. What does that mean?
    

  

### Chapter 23: Political Paralysis in the Gilded Age

The Hayes-Tilden Standoff, 1876

- What efforts were made to keep Grant from running for a third term?
    
- Why was Ohio so important?
    
- What happened in three of the states during the election of 1876?
    
- What does the election of 1876 reveal about the nature of political corruption in the 19th Century?
    

The Compromise of 1877 & the End of Reconstruction

- How was the electoral dispute in 1877 resolved?
    
- What was the peace that was brought by the 1877 resolution? What was the price?
    

The Birth of Jim Crow in Post-Reconstruction South

- The end of reconstruction meant what for both freedmen and poor whites?
    
- What does the chart on page 513 reveal about the nature of race relations during the post-war South?
    

Class Conflicts and Ethnic Clashes

- Kennedy mentions that 1877 marked the beginning of class warfare ‚Äì what does he mean by this?
    
- What efforts did organized labor seek to gain recognition in this time period?
    
- How did racial tensions increase during this time period?
    
- How did the Kearneyites react with the arrival of Chinese to California?
    

  

### Chapter 26: The Great West and the Agricultural Revolution

Introduction & The Clash of Cultures on the Plains

- What were the numbers regarding First Nations‚Äô population in 1860?
    
- Was the clash with white pioneers ‚Äúinevitable?‚Äù
    
- What dangers to First Nations‚Äô existence did the white settlers bring with them?
    
- What was the objectives of the reservation system?
    

Receding Native Population

- How did ‚Äúcruelty begot cruelty‚Äù as Kennedy described it?
    
- Describe the nature of the conflicts between whites and Native Americans.
    

Bellowing Herds of Bison ü¶¨¬†

- How did the destruction of the Bison hasten the capitulation of the First Nations?
    

The End of the Trail

- Describe how the 1880s relations began to change between First Nations and whites.
    
- Explain how this change in attitude did little to change the ultimate nature of the relationship.
    
- Describe the impact of the Dawes Act.
    

Mining: From Dishpan to Ore Breaker

- What was the economic impact of the mining industry of the west?
    
- How did ‚ÄúBeef Barons‚Äù arise in the west?
    
- What was the ‚ÄúLong Drive‚Äù?
    
- What was the impact of the winter of 1887 ‚Äì 1888?
    

Beef Bonanzas and the Long Drive

- How did ‚ÄúBeef Barons‚Äù arise in the west?
    
- What was the ‚ÄúLong Drive‚Äù?
    
- What was the impact of the winter of 1887 ‚Äì 1888?
    

The Farmers‚Äô Frontier

- How was the Homestead Act the ‚Äúbackbone‚Äù of democracy?
    
- How was the Homestead Act often a cruel joke?
    
- How did the farmers adapt to the realities of the ‚ÄúGreat American Basin‚Äù? How did it turn out to be the cause for later disaster?
    

¬†The Far West comes of Age

- Why were so many states added in the 1880s and 1890s?
    

¬†¬†The Fading Frontier

- Who was Frederick Jackson Turner and what was his thesis regarding American history?
    
- How was the frontier a state of mind as well as a physical location?
    
- How did the American conversion to industrial capitalism affect the Farmer?
    

The Farm Becomes a Factory

- How did the state of borrowing and the dramatic reduction in prices hurt the typical farmer?
    
- How did global markets affect the Farming business?
    
- By the year 1890 ‚Äì what was the situation for the typical farmer?
    

Unhappy Farmers

- Despite being nearly one-half of the nation‚Äôs population, why were farmers seemingly powerless?
    
- As if things weren‚Äôt bad enough for the farmers, by the end of the 1880s, what geographic conditions were they facing?
    
- How did the plight of the farmers reflect the new sectionalism of the late 19th Century?
    

¬†The Farmers Take Their Stand

- What was the purpose of the Grange Movement?
    
- How powerful did the movement become by the 1870s?
    

Prelude to Populism

- How was the Farmers‚Äô Alliance different from the Grange?
    
- How was racism the greatest weakness of the Farmers‚Äô Alliance?
    
- Who were the Populists?
    
- What was the Populist fascination with the coinage of silver?
    

  

## Unit 2: A Reason To Believe

### Chapter 23: Political Paralysis in the Gilded Age

Garfield and Arthur

- What was the makeup of the Republican Presidential Ticket in 1880? How was it a source of potential conflict?
    
- What was the one positive result that happened because of Garfield‚Äôs assassination?
    
- Why was Arthur an unlikely instrument of reform?
    
- How effective was civil service reform?
    
- Why was Arthur turned aside by the Republican Party in 1884?
    

  

The Blaine-Cleveland Mudslinger of 1884

- Describe Blaine‚Äôs candidacy for the presidency in 1884.
    
- Describe ‚ÄúGrover the Good.‚Äù
    
- Kennedy maintains that, ‚Äúpersonalities, not principles, claimed the headlines.‚Äù What does that mean?
    
- What role did Irish-Americans play in the election of 1884
    

  

‚ÄúOld Grover‚Äù Takes Over

- How does Kennedy describe Cleveland (not just in physical terms)?
    
- What was Cleveland‚Äôs attitude toward:
    

- Government intervention of the economy
    
- Civil service reform
    
- The North-South Gap
    
- Military Pensions
    

  

Cleveland Battles for a Lower Tariff

- What was Cleveland‚Äôs view on the tariff?
    
- The election of 1888 was going to hinge on what major issue?
    

  

The Billion Dollar Congress

- Describe the election results of 1888 with respect to the presidency and Congress.
    
- While a high tariff was wanted by Republicans ‚Äì what did a high tariff do to farmers?
    
- The election of 1890 did what to the Republicans?
    

  
  
  

The Drumbeat of Discontent

- What was the political makeup and objective of the Populists?
    
- What was the silver-gold coinage issue?
    
- The labor unrest of the early 1890s indicated what political realities?
    
- Why was Populism doomed given the political and racial realities of the 1890s?
    
- Kennedy indicates that by 1896, Populism had degenerated into racist platforms. Why?
    

  

Cleveland and Depression

- What helped Cleveland win in 1892?
    
- What caused the Depression of 1893?
    
- What effect did the Depression of 1893 have on the American political and economic condition?
    
- How did J.P. Morgan save the United States from financial ruin in 1895?
    

  

Cleveland Breeds a Backlash

- What was a result of the Morgan bond deal?
    
- Why did it appear that government was not responsive to the needs of the average American in the 1890s?
    
- Kennedy describes Congress and the leading branch during the Gilded Age. Why?
    

  

### Chapter 26: The Great West and the Agricultural Revolution

The Farmers Take Their Stand

- What was the purpose of the Grange Movement?
    
- How powerful did the movement become by the 1870s?
    

  

Prelude to Populism

- How was the Farmers‚Äô Alliance different from the Grange?
    
- How was racism the greatest weakness of the Farmers‚Äô Alliance?
    
- Who were the Populists?
    
- What was the Populist fascination with the coinage of silver?
    

  

Coxey‚Äôs Army and the Pullman Strike

- What was the perception of the Farmers‚Äô as to how the economy was treating them?
    
- What was Coxey‚Äôs Army?
    
- What did Coxey want?
    
- Who was Debs and what was his position with the Pullman Car Strike of 1894?
    
- What was Chicago the center of labor strife?
    

  

Golden McKinley and Silver Bryan

- Describe the election of 1896 with respect to nominees and their platforms.
    
- Mark Hanna had a very distinct view of government ‚Äì what was it?
    
- Why were the Democrats hopelessly divided in 1896?
    
- What was the big deal about coinage?
    

  

Class Conflict: Plow-holders Versus Bondholders

- Describe Bryan as a campaigner.
    
- Did money influence the election of 1896?
    
- What did the election of 1896 reveal about the appeal of Bryan and Populism?
    
- How was the election ‚Äúa new era in American politics?‚Äù
    
- What did the election reveal about American ideals?
    

  

Republican Stand-pattism Enthroned

- How was McKinley blessed with respect to the economy in 1897?
    
- How did new gold deposits help McKinley and the US?
    

### Chapter 28: Progressivism and the Republican Roosevelt (1901 ‚Äì 1912)

  

Introduction & Progressive Roots

- In the view of the progressives, what was wrong with American society?
    
- What solutions did they propose to address social problems?
    
- Why was progressive reform more attractive to middle-class Americans than the working classes or the wealthier segments of society?
    
- What were the major sources of the Progressive movement?
    

  

Raking Muck with the Muckrakers

- Why did journalistic ‚Äúmuckrakers‚Äù play such a large role in the progressive movement?
    
- Who and What were the targets of the muckrakers
    

  

Political Progressivism

- According to the progressives, what was the cure for all of American democracy‚Äôs ills?
    
- What were the two main objectives of the progressives?
    
- What was a third goal of the progressives?
    

  

Progressivism in the Cities and States

  

Progressive Women

- What were the distinctive contributions of feminists to the progressive movement?
    

  

TR‚Äôs Square Deal for Labor

- Would you classify Roosevelt as a radical, liberal, moderate or conservative? Why?
    
- Identify the three C‚Äôs of Roosevelt‚Äôs Square Deal.
    
- How did the Square Deal succeed in its goal of using the federal government to mediate between powerful interests?
    

  

TR Corrals the Corporations

- TR was often labeled as the ‚Äútrust - buster.‚Äù How accurate is this reputation?¬†
    

  

Caring for the Consumer

- How did consumer protection reveal the progressive soul?¬†
    

  

Earth Control

- How did environmentalism reveal the progressive soul?
    
- Why did TR consider conservation perhaps his greatest achievement as president?
    

  

The ‚ÄúRoosevelt Panic‚Äù of 1907

- How did TR make a tactical mistake during the night of his election?
    
- What did the Panic of 1907 do for both Roosevelt and the financial industry?
    

  

The Rough Rider Thunders Out

- Roosevelt is sometimes called the first modern president. Does this description fit?¬†
    

  

Taft: A Round Peg in a Square Hole

- What were some of the major weaknesses of Taft‚Äôs personality that threatened his presidency?¬†
    

  

Taft the Trustbuster

- What was Taft‚Äôs reputation as a trust-buster?¬†
    

  
  
  

Taft Splits the Republican Party

- Why was the tariff such a controversial issue during the Taft administration?
    
- How did Taft handle conservation?
    
- How did the Congressional elections of 1910 further weaken Taft?
    

  

The Taft-Roosevelt Rupture

- Is the claim that Taft abandoned Roosevelt‚Äôs policies accurate? Why?
    
- How did TR get himself back into presidential politics in 1912?
    

  

### Chapter 29: Wilsonian Progressivism at Home and Abroad (1912 ‚Äì 1916)

The ‚ÄúBull Moose‚Äù Campaign of 1912

- Compare and contrast Roosevelt's New Nationalism and Wilson's New Freedom programs. Which seems to you to be the more realistic response to industrialization? Why?
    
- Compare the issues and candidates in the presidential elections of 1912 and 1916. Account for Wilson's victory in each case.
    

  

Woodrow Wilson: A Minority President

- What were the electoral results of 1912?
    
- Why was the Progressive Party such a failure?
    

  

Wilson: The Idealist in Politics

- Critically evaluate Woodrow Wilson's personal qualities as well as his presidential leadership and policies. How did his personality affect his policies and their outcome?
    

  

Wilson Tackles the Tariff

- What was the triple wall of privilege?
    

  

Wilson Battles the Bankers

- Why was the Federal Reserve Act a ‚Äúred-letter achievement?‚Äù
    

  

The President Tames the Trusts

  
  
  
  
  

Wilsonian Progressivism at High Tide

- What were the most important of Wilson's progressive reforms? Was Wilson actually a more effective progressive than Theodore Roosevelt? Why or why not?
    
- Comment on the observation that Wilson's support for the flood of social‚Äîwelfare legislation in 1916 was ‚Äúhypocritical and self‚Äîserving.‚Äù

## Final Checklist

STUDENTS WILL UNDERSTAND:

- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Industrial growth led to social and government reforms.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Government's role as a regulator and catalyst of industrial economy became more acceptable.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The upheaval of industrial America led to and added to already existing discrimination against new immigrants, Native Americans and Black Americans.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Industrialization was made possible by America‚Äôs abundant natural resources, a socially mobile population, an inventive spirit and a supportive government.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Industrialization dramatically changed the demographics of the United States while accentuating regional and economic differences.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The rise of labor organizations was concurrent with the rise of industrial magnates.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Changes in American economic system fostered dramatic changes in American society.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Both the Populist and Progressive Movements were complicated, in some cases contradictory, movements that still endure today.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Both the Populist and Progressive Movements engaged in actions that could be considered ill-conceived through the benefit of hindsight.
    

  

STUDENTS WILL KNOW:

- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The causes of America‚Äôs transformation from an agricultural to an industrial society.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The causes behind and the impact of increased European immigration in the late 19th and early 20th Centuries.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The limits of the Populist / Progressive Movements with respect to non-white, non-Christian, non-Anglo-Saxon peoples.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The problems faced by the various immigrant groups that entered the United States. (examples include: suspected political
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    affiliations, suspicion of non-heterosexual relations)
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The impact of industrial life on living patterns in America.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The way in which the plight of Black Americans was almost wholly ignored by Progressive Era leaders.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    How the industrial era transformed the role of government in its relationship with the national economy.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The major accomplishments and shortcomings of the Progressive Movement.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    How the Women's Suffrage Movement (see WWI and 1920s units for more) excluded Black woman from its efforts and activities.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    How industrialization spawned reform movements and reformers of enduring legacy.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The positive and negative features of the industrial leaders of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    How the role of women in American public life began to fundamentally change in the late 19th and early 20th Century.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The major muckrakers and their impact on reforming American life.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The ability of some women to cohabitate, sometimes romantically, without much attention or suspicion given to their relationships. This is sometimes referred to as a ‚ÄúBoston Marriage.‚Äù
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    The differing viewpoints of the Progressive Presidents (Theodore Roosevelt, William Taft and Woodrow Wilson) and how they saw the Progressive movement in different lights.
    

  

STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:

- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Identify and describe the core vocabulary terms relevant to the era of reform.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Identify and describe differences between primary and secondary sources of history.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Interpret history through charts and graphs.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Formulate written responses to challenging questions concerning the impact of industrialization and offer historically valid assessments about controversial historical topics therein.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Compare and contrast laissez-faire capitalism with a regulated economy.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Analyze charts, graphs, and political cartoons to draw conclusions about the impact of industrialization in America.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Identify biases present in historical accounts.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Identify correct answers on multiple choice tests and quizzes.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Generate conclusions about historical events, people and movements.
    
- ![unchecked](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Demonstrate knowledge of American History through a variety of assessment methods.
